;;中国目前约占 Mirxes 收入的 20%联合创始人兼首席执行官周立涵表示，该公司仍在等待监管部门的批准，并且在那里的业务活动有限。图片：南华早报讲义;
;

;周表示，中国内地将成为新加坡诊断初创公司Mirxes核心产品的最大单一市场，胃癌检测试剂盒是该公司发展的关键Lihan，其首席执行官兼联合创始人。

;

;这家生物技术公司于 2019 年推出了世界上第一个用于早期检测胃癌的分子诊断试剂盒，并于 4 月份重新提交了香港首次公开募股的招股说明书草案目标是筹集至少 1 亿美元，估值约为 6 亿美元。

;

;Mirxes 于去年 7 月首次申请在香港证券交易所上市，但后来取消了该计划。

;

;周说，由于中国房地产市场危机和加沙战争等因素，2023 年底是“一个非常动荡的时期”，“我们觉得现在不是继续前进的正确时机”。

;

;根据最新招股书，该公司2023年营收同比增长36.2%至2420万美元，但净亏损6960万美元，较上年亏损扩大23.8%

;
;
;

;中国目前约占 Mirxes 收入的 20%，因为该公司仍在等待监管部门批准，并且在中国的业务活动有限。不过，周预计，继 GastroClear 预计于今年最后一个季度在中国推出后，中国市场占总收入的比例将翻倍。

;

;“中国市场至关重要，因为它将为我们提供初步规模，从而降低成本，”周说。 “当我们瞄准其他市场，特别是东南亚市场时，这种规模将使我们在财务上非常强大。”

;

;他说，中国的胃癌患者占全球胃癌患者的一半，超过 6 亿中国人符合资格用于筛选。因此，中国对 Mirxes 检测试剂盒批准后的需求可能会将公司的毛利率从约 50% 提高到 70%。

;

;“一旦我们达到这个目标，它将帮助我们潜在地减少这位科学家出身的企业家说道：“这不仅可以降低消费者的价格，还可以使整个过程更具成本效益。”

;

;该生物技术公司于 11 月完成了该试剂盒的临床试验，并提交了注册申请下个月向中国国家药品监督管理局 (NMPA) 提出申请。

;

;“您可以将今年视为我们为未来几年进行重大商业推广的准备年，”周说。

;

; >;

;Mirxes 的目标是在未来六个月内完成股票发行，并在 IPO 之前加紧推进其商业化进程。

;

;“我们非常专注……准备必要的商业渠道来实现这些周说。

;

;由于 GastroClear 是市场上第一个用于早期检测胃癌的分子血液检测，Mirxes 将承担起周说，我们有责任向该领域的其他人宣传分子测试如何帮助筛查疾病。

;

;虽然该公司自在杭州市开展业务以来已在中国拥有坚实的基础，但在浙江省省会，2016年，内窥镜检查仍然是中国胃癌筛查和诊断的金标准。

;

;Mirxes面临的一个主要挑战是通过保险等方式获得该产品的广泛报销，Zhou

;

;“当我们进行筛查时，大多数亚洲国家的全国覆盖范围，无论是公共的还是私人的，都还不成熟，”他说。 “我们仍处于知道如何获得治疗疾病报销的阶段，但不知道如何获得预防疾病的报销。”

;

;这一障碍可能会限制产品在前 5% 以外的快速扩张。他说。

;

;“这是我们需要开始解决的一个长期问题，”他补充说，需要随着时间的推移确定获得最大收益所需的测试频率，这与报销挂钩。

;

;周说，Mirxes 可能决定将 IPO 筹集的资金的一半用于将更多产品推向市场，包括结直肠癌和肝癌的诊断产品。

;;香港当代文化学院李兆基创意书院本月早些时候透露其服务器遭到黑客攻击。图片：谷歌地图;
;

;香港一所中学表示，其服务器本月早些时候遭到黑客攻击，过去四年来学生、教职员工和家长的个人信息被封锁。;;

; p>;

;位于九龙城的香港当代文化学院李兆基创意书院周六证实了这一事件。

;

;IT人员于5月13日发现，大约8名学生的访问被封锁。数 TB 的学校数据，包含过去四年中学生、家长和教职员工的个人详细信息，包括 2021 年毕业的学生。

;

;有关学校租户、合作组织和行政文件的信息

;

;“学校立即关闭校园网络，以防止影响蔓延”，并补充说，已向教育局和警方等当局报告了此次黑客攻击事件。

;

;“我们已经通知了学生和家长，一旦数据恢复，我们将继续联系受影响的校友、租户和组织。”

;

;学校表示目前尚不清楚数据是否已泄露，但敦促人们提防奇怪的通信尝试。

;

;它还表示，全校范围内的计算机扫描和重新安装工作预计将持续一周左右，同时临时互联网出于教学目的，将制定访问计划。

;

;学校表示：“对于给受影响的人带来的不便，我们深表歉意。”该局表示，据了解，学校已立即采取措施行动，并敦促其进行全面调查，并彻底检视其信息系统。

;

;上个月，大围仁安医院透露，该医院遭受勒索软件攻击，工作人员在处理后发现发现其网络系统出现异常，包括一些计算机文件丢失。

;

;黑客随后向医院索要1000万美元的赎金，但医院拒绝支付。

;;中国 Z 世代人群的影响力和消费潜力使他们成为许多大大小小的品牌的主要目标群体。图片来源：Shutterstock;
;

;与许多中国大陆的 Z 世代同龄人一样，Judy Xu 每天平均花 7 个小时在社交媒体上，了解最新的时尚趋势。但这位来自上海的24岁营销专业人士并不热衷于追随当前流行的东西。

;

;“我更愿意为产品的设计支付更高的价格，如果它足够特别，那么我找不到其他地方，”徐说。 “我也关心这件商品是否符合我的个性，这反映了我的审美观。”

;

;市场上有这么多选择，徐说她会坚持“任何符合我风格的品牌”，而不仅仅是一个这种观点反映了徐和她的 Z 世代同胞（根据智库皮尤研究中心的数据，出生于 1997 年至 2012 年之间的人）将如何影响商品的营销方式。中国很快就会成为世界第二大经济体消费的主要推动力。

;
;;
;;5月的上海南京路商圈2024 年 1 月 1 日。图片：彭博社;
;
;

;Z 世代已成为亚太地区增长最快的人口群体，预计将占大陆人口的 21%毕马威中国的一份报告显示，到 2025 年，总人口将增加。

;

;虽然 Z 世代的影响力和消费潜力使他们成为许多品牌的主要目标群体，但 Z 世代也可能是一个难以捉摸的市场。< /p>;

;“Z 世代与众不同，”上海数字机构 VO2 Asia Pacific 联合创始人 Sophie Coulon 说道，该机构的客户包括多个主要国际品牌。

;

;“他们一直在不同的环境中长大，这意味着他们没有经历父母和祖父母的所有艰辛。他们是数字原住民，因此他们希望事情能够超级快地完成，”库伦说。 “但与此同时，他们也面临着一些来自社会的压力。他们希望能够表达自己，因此购买衣服是展示[他们]身份的一种方式。这不仅仅是‘因为你拥有一个包，你就是一个人物’。”

;
;
;

;尽管如此，Z 世代的消费能力仍然让许多品牌无法抗拒。根据消费者研究公司凯度消费者指数 (Kantar Worldpanel) 编制的数据，2023 年，15 至 24 岁的消费者创造了 930 亿元人民币（129 亿美元）的收入，占中国 4,240 亿元美容市场的 22.1%。

;

;该公司发现，该群体在美容产品上的花费比 64 岁以下的老年群体高出 44%。

;

;中国的 Z 世代，尤其是来自中国一线城市的 Z 世代，具有巨大的影响力上海社会科学院研究员杨建文表示，通过推动社交媒体和互联网趋势来塑造消费。

;

;在中国的高净值人群中，Z 世代也将成为普华永道最近的一份报告显示，未来十年，他们将成为奢侈品牌重点关注的关键群体。

;
;
;

;上海社会科学院的杨表示，Z世代在中国仍执行独生子女政策期间成长，得到了家庭最大的照顾和支持，获得了更多的可支配收入，这让他们更愿意花钱。< /p>;

;国际品牌已经注意到这一点，并正在巩固其战略，以赢得这些年轻中国消费者的青睐。

;

;“截至 2023 年，我们实际上拥有高达 60% 的品牌我们的销售额来自中国的千禧一代和 Z 世代，这确实是我们评估我们的品牌是否准备在中国长期稳定增长的重要指标。”施华洛世奇首席执行官亚历克西斯·纳萨尔 (Alexis Nasard) 在上个月接受采访时表示与南华早报的报道。

;

;中国约占这家奥地利水晶制造商业务的 15%，去年该公司的全球零售额为 18 亿欧元（19 亿美元）。施华洛世奇在一份声明中表示，这一数字较上年同期增长了 4%，在充满波动的充满挑战的市场中“远高于整体增长”。

;
;;
;;中国的 Z 世代，尤其是来自中国一线城市的 Z 世代，通过推动社交媒体趋势，在塑造消费方面具有巨大影响力。照片：Shutterstock;
;
;

;然而，品牌面临的问题是 Z 世代的品味可能变化无常或难以确定。

;

;总部位于上海营销专业人士 Nicole Xu（与来自同城的 Judy Xu 没有关系）表示，她个人并不认同目前社交媒体上风靡一时的“安静奢华”趋势，“因为我觉得它看起来很无聊”。;

;24岁的徐用她的第一张工资支票挥霍购买了香奈儿包包，并表示她愿意花“很多钱来购买该品牌所代表的设计和社会身份”。她还指出，她的日常衣橱里有 H&M 和 Zara 等大众市场品牌的单品，这些单品“只会在我的衣橱里呆一两季”。

;

;虽然这个人群倾向于与年长消费者相比，他们的地位意识较低，更加务实，“品牌必须有自己不可替代的差异性，因为我们发现 Z 世代更喜欢具有生活方式传统的品牌，提供情感价值、设计和产品体验”，Kantar 的 Jason Yu 表示。大中华区董事总经理补充道，Z 世代消费者往往比年长的同龄人不太注重地位，但更加务实。

;
;;
;;人物走过北京商业区的一家施华洛世奇专卖店。图片来源：EPA-EFE;
;
;

;“国外品牌正面临着被中国高品质、高性价比的国产品牌崛起所取代的压力，”于说。他补充说，因此，像施华洛世奇这样在国内没有直接竞争对手且提供同等产品的品牌在市场上保持着一定的红利。

;

;施华洛世奇首席执行官纳加德表示，他发现 Z 世代的品味更加细致入微。 “西方奢侈品牌拥有一些有趣且独特的藏品，但如果本地替代品能够给他们带来他们期望从品牌或产品中获得的价值，他们对本地替代品越来越开放，”他说。

;

;他补充说，根据公司的观察，Z 世代消费者比年龄稍大的千禧一代消费者更愿意尝试更大胆的单品。

;
;;
;;行人走过香港中环的一家 Ralph Lauren 商店。图片来源：Bloomberg;
;
;

;对于美国时尚品牌Ralph Lauren来说，该公司之所以选择在北京三里屯商场开设第一家Ralph Coffee店，是因为它“吸引了很多年轻、时尚的消费者”大中华区及东南亚地区首席执行官蔡信辉 (Chua Shin Hwee) 表示。她表示，Ralph Lauren 经常根据不同城市的人口统计数据定制其商店。

;

;“我们崇尚乐观。我们是为了自由。我们谈论的是创业精神。 Ralph Lauren 总裁兼首席执行官 Patrice Louvet 上个月告诉《华盛顿邮报》，他相信这些价值观能引起年轻消费者的共鸣。中国目前占 Ralph Lauren 全球销售额的 7%据路透社报道。根据该公司 2 月份的财报电话会议，Ralph Lauren 在本财年第二季度和第三季度期间在亚洲的总体收入增长了 16%。

;

;Ralph Lauren 在中国的强劲表现可归因于普华永道中国可持续发展战略与转型高级经理 Sheila Cheng 表示，该品牌的年轻化设计及其在社交媒体上引起的轰动，尤其是在小红书等生活方式平台上。

;

;然而，郑警告说，奢侈品品牌不再主要关注内地年轻消费者。 “他们更容易受到经济波动的影响，”她说。 “经济不好的时候，他们的消费能力就比较低。因此，她补充说，奢侈品牌应该关注超级富裕消费者作为其核心客户群。

; Sun, 19 May 2024 10:20:02 +0800 Hong Kong needs to start decarbonising its buildings. Here’s howhttps://www.scmp.com/opinion/hong-kong-opinion/article/3262681/hong-kong-needs-start-decarbonising-its-buildings-heres-how?utm_source=rss_feed
;;2024.05.19 09:30;
;;
;;去年深水埗的建筑物景观。在香港，建筑物的碳排放量占60%以上，远高于全球平均水平。图片：May Tse;
;

;自第 28 届联合国气候变化大会上 110 多个国家同意将能源效率提高一倍至每年 4% 以来，已经过去五个多月了。旨在达成《巴黎协定》的协议。此后香港做了什么？

;

;在环境政策的许多领域，香港都遵循国际惯例。它最近采用了可持续金融分类法，寻求与中国政府和欧盟发布的指导方针保持一致。这涵盖了建筑翻新贷款，并包括上市公司报告气候变化影响和风险的标准。

;

;早在 2009 年，香港就推出了类似于欧盟标准的强制性家用电器能效标签计划（我在 20 世纪 90 年代初参与开发）。该市在环境问题上的协调有着悠久的历史。但还没有在建筑物中。这就是可以采取紧急行动来实现 Cop28 目标的地方。

;

;欧盟于 2002 年推出了针对已售或租赁建筑的能源绩效证书 (EPC) 体系，A 级最好，G 最差。从未出售或租赁的大型公共建筑必须携带显示能源证书（DEC）以显示其实际用途。

;

;这里有一个重要的点。建筑物的评级（在理想情况下建模）可能与其实际使用时的使用情况有很大不同。可以说，EPC 和 DEC 都是需要的，特别是对于大型建筑。建筑物经常出现过冷和过亮的情况，空荡荡的房间里经常开着灯。

;

;最近，欧盟决定修订其《建筑物能源绩效指令》，要求所有新建建筑物都必须净电到 2030 年实现零碳排放，并制定了现有建筑脱碳的时间表。香港是时候效仿了吗？

;
;
;

;香港的建筑能源使用政策薄弱。在香港，建筑物的碳排放量占60%以上，远高于约39%的全球平均水平。然而，香港的目标只是到 2050 年（而不是 2030 年）所有新建筑实现净零排放，并且似乎没有翻新现有建筑的时间表。

;

;令人困惑的是，香港有几项自愿建筑能源标签计划，包括建筑研究机构环境评估方法 (BREEAM)、能源与环境设计领导力 (LEED) 和零碳建筑认证计划 - 所有这些都在狭小的空间内进行新建和翻新建筑的竞争。改进新建筑只会降低排放增加的速度。为了减少排放，香港必须关注所有建筑物。

;

;那么香港需要什么？首先，它需要在销售或租赁点应用强制性建筑能源标签。强制性标签是跟踪市场建筑效率变化的基础。

;

;它是其他政策的基础，例如对最差的建筑征收更多的税，对更好的建筑征收更少的税，或者改造的补贴计划（在在欧洲，能源效率翻新通常由电力和天然气公用事业公司支付）。该标签可以用来表明，最差的建筑物除非达到能源效率标准，否则不能出租或出售。

;

;本月早些时候，气候债券倡议组织发布了一份题为“脱碳的 20 个政策杠杆”的报告欧洲建筑”，建立在强制性能源标签的基础上，采取从教育、技能和培训到财政激励、公共采购举措和绿色抵押贷款等措施。

;

;很简单，没有强制性能源标签建筑物，效率没有市场，巴黎气候目标的进展也很小。

;
;;
;;可制作住宅建筑通过改变空调来提高能源效率。照片：Edmond So;
;
;

;

;慢慢移动，您可能会看着这些鸟在喂食，更加挑剔，甚至打zing着。但是任何突然的运动，他们都会迅速飞走：提醒他们的生活充满了危险，与人类最大的危险。

;

;在香港，鸟儿没有被猎杀，但仍然面临许多问题无论是全年还是在移民参观的季节，可能会长期住宿。复杂的深湾，实际上很浅 - 它在海岸上占据了深层的凹痕，由香港和深圳共享。

;

;

;

;全球，诸如深湾等潮汐公寓长期以来一直受到人类的转变。 ，尤其是为农业，水产养殖和定居点创造新的土地。

;

;

;

;澳大利亚昆士兰州大学和詹姆斯·库克大学的研究人员最近进行的一项研究，标题为“全球保护区的覆盖范围和人类对潮汐公寓的压力”，据估计，在1984年至2016年之间，世界上有16％的潮汐公寓损失，东亚尤其明显。

;

;评估珍珠河三角洲的评估发现，在过去的半个世纪中，长度为自然海岸线从136.91公里（85英里）下降到15.17公里，填海覆盖约282平方公里（109平方英里），相当于香港总土地总面积的四分之一。

;

;
; ; ;圣锡的鱼池。政府计划摧毁鱼池的大量区域，以建造一部分圣锡technopole。照片：Martin Williams ;
; ;

;这是一个奇迹，深湾已经幸存了下来。肯定有助于新地区的边界划分为该地区，离开南岸，作为香港农村腹地的一部分。

;

;自1970年代以来的发展压力加剧了，虽然Deep Bay的部分地区也得到了保护。 ，尤其是在Mai Po Marshes中，保护措施通常缺乏野心，甚至胆怯。 new protected areas are promised, other developments loom, making 2024 pivotal in the history of Deep Bay.

;
;;
;;Cormorants fly over Shenzhen, seen from the Fung Lok Wai fish ponds. Photo: Martin Williams;
;
;

;In a 1978 article that was part of the “Geography and the Environment in Southeast Asia” collection of papers, author David Lai Chuen-yan noted that about half of the bay was covered by dwarf mangroves and salt marshes in 1957, yet the 1950s also saw the beginning of extensive reclamation of these areas.

;

;Raised embankments known as bunds were built, to create areas where salt-tolerant rice was grown, and ducks and poultry were reared, along with fish ponds and gei wai – ponds that could be filled at high tide, and emptied at low tide to harvest shrimp. By 1969, the gei wai and fish ponds covered almost half of the total area.

;

;Many waterbirds took a liking to the new ponds, particularly the gei wai at Mai Po, leading to a visit by renowned British conservationist Peter Scott, who had established the Wildfowl Trust in 1946 and, in 1961, was a key founder of the World Wildlife Fund (WWF).

;
;;
;;A black-winged stilt seen from the San Tin fish ponds. Photo: Martin Williams;
;
;

;Scott recommended the establishment of a reserve at Mai Po, an idea echoed by the government's Provisional Council for the Use and Conservation of the Countryside in 1968.

;

;“Local conservationists were astonished by a newspaper report on 16 March 1975 that the government had given its basic approval to the Canadian Overseas Development Company (CODC) to develop 116 ha [hectares] of fish-farming land at Tai Shang Wai [adjoining Mai Po] into a large housing estate for about 30,000 people,” noted Lai in his 1978 article.

;

;Looking back on the case in 1990, then conservation director of WWF-Hong Kong, David Melville, remarked, “This was the period when the rot set in – there has been a lot of new development since then.”

;

;Yet, as Melville related, “Two members of the Hong Kong Bird Watching Society, Mike Webster and Fred Hechtel, petitioned the government to get some sort of conservation measures.

;

;“Without their action, we may have lost Mai Po, which was declared a site of special scientific interest. This increases the awareness of planners that a place is important.”

;

;The housing project went ahead, becoming the upscale suburb of Fairview Park, and in the process destroyed Hong Kong's last nesting site for the pheasant-tailed jacana, a handsome lily-trotter.

;

;Also, in 1982, the government approved a request from the newly established WWF-Hong Kong to develop a nature reserve at Mai Po. Two years later, the reserve was officially established, and the following year WWF-Hong Kong began work on the Mai Po Marshes Wildlife Education Centre and Nature Reserve.

;
;;
;;Shrimp farmers fish in Mai Po in 1989, when some rights to ponds were still owned by shrimp farmers. Photo: Martin Williams;
;
;

;“Mai Po” has since become nearly synonymous with the Deep Bay wetland. Changes in the early years included a boardwalk through the adjacent mangroves to the mudflats, where a hide enabled unprecedented views of birds in the heart of the bay.

;

;Helped by this plus a lagoon created by combining two gei wai, bird observations increased, with regular sightings of global rarities such as the spoon-billed sandpiper making Mai Po renowned among birdwatchers worldwide.

;

;The sandpiper is a birdwatcher's bird – typically grey above, white below, barely larger than a sparrow, distinguished for being the only shorebird with a flattened tip to its bill. Soon, however, there was a star bird with more widespread appeal, also with a spoon-shaped bill.

;

;Black-faced spoonbills had been seen regularly in winters since the 1950s, and even though restricted to East Asia they were almost taken for granted until hotshot birdwatcher Peter Kennerley noticed a dearth of information on them, and sent out requests for sightings.

;
;;
;;Black-faced spoonbills fly above Mai Po. Photo: Martin Williams;
;
;

;In 1990, he published the best total he could calculate for the entire world population: 288. Suddenly, the black-faced spoonbill had the dubious distinction of being classed as critically endangered, breeding in northeast Asia, and with only three key winter sites: one in each of Taiwan and Vietnam, and Deep Bay.

;

;Standing around 75cm tall and resembling a stout white egret, though with a spatulate bill, the spoonbill became a flagship species, featuring in media articles about Deep Bay and Mai Po.

;

;Largely as the bay supported significant numbers of this and other migratory waterbirds, it qualified for listing as a wetland of international importance under the United Nations' Ramsar Convention.

;

;After years of lobbying by Melville and others, the government agreed to apply for listing, and in 1995 Inner Deep Bay became a Ramsar Site, initially through the British government, and through the China government from 1997.

;
;;
;;Great cormorants and cattle egrets on electrical wires at San Tin. Photo: Martin Williams;
;
;

;To safeguard the Ramsar Site, and aim for the “wise use” of wetland called for in the convention, the Hong Kong government established zones ranging from the mudflats in the core, to a buffer zone dominated by fish ponds, with regulations restricting the types of developments permitted.

;

;By then, it was too late to save around 5 sq km of fish ponds and farmland near Yuen长的。 This had been bought by the impressively named, now defunct Mightycity Company, which in the 1980s began covering the area with sand and rubble, for construction of the Tin Shui Wai new town.

;

;By accident, pools and grassland on the reclaimed area attracted a variety of birds, and in 1998 the government decided to build the Hong Kong Wetland Park to mitigate their loss.

;

;With the year 2000 approaching, the wetland park morphed into one of the government's Millennium Projects, involving the Tourism Commission along with the Agriculture, Fisheries and Conservation Department.

;

;By the time it opened, in 2006, around HK$500 million had been spent on facilities including an expansive visitor centre featuring a walk-in Arctic diorama complete with a caribou specimen, an exhibit with Indian crocodiles swimming amid life-size replicas of mangrove trees, and a 3D theatre with moving seats (and work is under way on new exhibits, with more relevance to local wetlands).

;

;Outside, water was pumped down an artificial cascade to an almost sterile freshwater area; and at the far end of the park there was a tidal lagoon that became the only good place for birds, yet occupied less than 10 per cent of the park's area and paled in comparison with Mai Po.

;

;Meanwhile, the rot continued. Deep Bay itself changed as mangroves spread, and the mudflat level rose, with more silt arriving when the Shenzhen River was straightened to alleviate the risk of flooding.

;

;The overall result was a reduced area of tidal flats where birds could feed. Village housing, scrapyards, vehicle repair yards, truck parks and former fields with containers stacked six high fringed the fish ponds, many of which fell into disuse given business challenges and uncertainties regarding the future.

;

;These uncertainties stemmed partly from developers large and small buying areas of fish ponds, with notions of profitable ventures.

;

;In the early 1990s, Henderson Land planned to build Sunnyville, a housing estate with a golf course on land near Mai Po.

;

;WWF-Hong Kong was initially supportive, especially as the developer planned to create a nature reserve by restoring an area of fish ponds to mangroves and marshes, but later joined an alliance opposing the scheme – given increased recognition that fish ponds are important for wildlife, plus the government better enforcing regulations that protect them.

;

;Court cases ensued, and Sunnyville eventually reached the High Court before being halted. It seems Henderson had set a precedent, however, as similar plans were announced for other fish pond areas, likewise with promises to compensate for destroying some fish ponds by landscaping and managing others nearby so they would attract more wildlife.

;

;Conservationists were sceptical of such benefits, and the grander plans were stalled.

;

;One of them – involving a partnership between WWF-Hong Kong and Cheung Kong, which aimed to build housing on part of a fish ponds area at Fung Lok Wai – was only brought to a halt after WWF-Hong Kong left the partnership in 2013, and Green Sense sought a judicial review the following year, leading to the Town Planning Board to reconsider the application six years later.

;
;;
;;Fish ponds in Fung Lok Wai, with Tin Shui Wai to the west and Shenzhen across Deep Bay. Photo: Martin Williams;
;
;

;Yet this did not mean Fung Lok Wai was safe from harm. In March 2022, the Town Planning Board won an appeal against the judicial review, and the next month an idea for developing it entirely, for housing covering an area larger than Tin Shui Wai, was raised in a board meeting.

;

;In response, representatives from the Planning Department, Civil Engineering and Development Department and Housing Department said the proposal was not in line with the planning intention of the area, which is zoned as “Comprehensive Development and Wetland Enhancement Area”.

;

;Meanwhile, on the north side of the bay, there were few such concerns about conservation after Shenzhen was established in 1979.

;

;A Nasa satellite image taken in 1988 shows extensive ponds and marshes; just eight years later these had gone, making way for new urban areas and reclamations ready for construction that continues today.

;

;Little but a belt of mangroves remains, afforded some protection in the Guangdong Futian Mangrove Nature Reserve.

;

;As Deep Bay was transformed, the wetland birdlife changed, too. Hearteningly, numbers of black-faced spoonbills surged, with 527 recorded during the 2022/23 winter.

;
;;
;;Fake mangroves inside the Hong Kong Wetland Park. Photo: Martin Williams;
;
;

;Yet this rise was due to factors well beyond Deep Bay, as the world population rapidly increased to more than 66,000 after Kennerley's wake-up call prompted conservation efforts from its breeding grounds in west Korea to multiple migration stopovers and winter haunts.

;

;The situation of other species is mixed, and while overall numbers fluctuate from year to year, the total number of waterbirds recorded in Deep Bay during winter rose to a high of more than 90,000 in early 2008 but has since fallen back to below 55,000.

;

;These tallies prompted researchers from the Chinese University of Hong Kong and the University of Essex, in Britain, to publish a paper in September 2023 titled “Rise and fall of an avian oasis: Tracking the impacts of land use change in a key coastal wetland in the world's largest megalopolis”, citing pollution and reclamation as key reasons for the declines of birds such as ducks and gulls.

;

;November 2023 saw the opening of the WWF Jockey Club Mai Po Peter Scott Visitor Centre, a building as grand as its name, rather resembling a city museum though with little to see inside, and with visitor numbers tightly restricted.

;

;This was built with a Jockey Club donation of HK$347 million (US$44 million) for infrastructure, including the visitor centre, upgrading footpaths and building two new viewing hides.

;
;;
;;The Hong Kong Wetland Park visitor centre, in Tin Shui Wai. Photo: Martin Williams;
;
;

;While humans benefit from the donation, it did not cover infrastructure for Mai Po's wildlife, such as the ponds and embankments that can likewise require revamps. The Jockey Club, WWF-Hong Kong and Peter Cornthwaite – CEO of WWF-Hong Kong as the infrastructure work was planned – declined to comment.

;

;Pond landscaping aside, day-to-day management of the habitats can be costly, and the reserve team struggles for adequate funds, despite annual financial support from the government topped up by fundraising events such as the Big Bird Race.

;

;One obvious way to generate more income would be allowing in more visitors.

;

;Worldwide, wetland reserves tend to welcome visitors, with fees helping support ongoing habitat improvements. Mai Po is an outlier, with a restrictive permit system and the Wetland Park supposedly more for the masses.

;

;It is somewhat ironic that Peter Scott is commemorated in the visitor centre's name – he was a strong advocate of bringing wildlife and people together; in 2023, the reserve he founded at Slimbridge in Britain attracted some 245,000 visitors, while the slightly larger Mai Po receives around 30,000 visitors per year, half of them schoolchildren.

;
;;
;;A pied kingfisher in flight over the San Tin fish ponds. Photo: Martin Williams;
;
;

;Plus, having more visitors can boost support for conservation measures. Consider, say, the public outcry as work began on a private project at Ham Tin, on the Sai Kung Peninsula, which is popular with hikers.

;

;A dedicated Facebook group attracted 46,000 members in just four days, and the publicity led to government intervention, putting an end to the project.

;

;In Deep Bay, by contrast, potential issues are typically contested by just a handful of green groups.

;

;The latest threat alarming green groups involves plans for siting part of the San Tin Technopole – a planned IT hub that will be a component of the Northern Metropolis, to be developed across Yuen Long and Northern District – on land that is currently fish ponds.

;

;“The massive pond filling-in and change of land uses will inevitably result in the loss of wetland area and its ecological function,” predicts WWF-Hong Kong in a submission to the government.

;

;“Data show that the San Tin fish ponds are important foraging, roosting and breeding habitats for waterbirds and the extremely rare Eurasian otter.”

;
;;
;;Avocets in Mai Po. Photo: Martin Williams;
;
;

;The plans for San Tin would seem to conflict with Town Planning Board guidelines, according to which, “new development within the wetland conservation area would not be allowed unless it is an essential infrastructural project with overriding public interest”.

;

;The Planning Department is yet to respond to an inquiry regarding the overriding reasons for part of the Technopole being built on the fish ponds area; Charles Wong Sai-chu, of the Civil Engineering and Development Department's Public Relations Unit, noted that flood attenuation facilities and revitalisation of drainage channels will further improve the drainage capacity while sidestepping a question about using wetlands rather than underground storage for flood alleviation.

;

;Much like the stalled developers' proposals, the Technopole plans call for enhancing nearby fish ponds within a wetland conservation park.

;

;Yet with no details forthcoming, green groups are sceptical this can mitigate for the loss of ponds; especially as the park may not be finalised till 2039, which Yu Yat-tung, director of the Hong Kong Bird Watching Society, describes as “not acceptable”.

;
;;
;;Yu Yat-tung (left), director of the Hong Kong Bird Watching Society, is filmed as he explains threats to the wetland area and conservation value. Photo: Martin Williams;
;
;

;According to Simon Chan Kin-fung, assistant director (conservation) of the Agriculture, Fisheries and Conservation Department, two more wetland conservation parks are planned, but will be based on experience with the first of the trio.

;

;Such caution apparently overlooks the wealth of expertise in managing wetland reserves in Hong Kong and worldwide, and the fact the wetland parks are almost ready-made, with scope for enhancements akin to Mai Po's ongoing evolution.

;

;As San Tin is on the Shenzhen River floodplain, the Technopole buildings here will require defences against rainstorms.

;

;In November 2023, Civil Engineering and Development Department project manager Tony Cheung Ka-leung revealed plans for underground facilities with a capacity of 200,000 cubic metres.

;

;Cheung also said fish ponds could not control floods properly, which is at odds with other government information – and the results of floodplain restoration projects in places such as Germany and California, in the United States, which have significantly reduced flooding along with enhancing climate-change adaptation.

;
;;
;;A black-faced spoonbill in Mai Po in 2018. Photo: Martin Williams;
;
;

;Suppose there could be less construction at San Tin, leaving room for protecting a wetland area 50 per cent larger than currently planned: “The remaining fish ponds […] can be developed as the Sam Po Shue Wetland Conservation Park covering an area of about 520 hectares,” with enhanced biodiversity and protection of birds' flight paths.

;

;Rather than being a green group's pipe dream, this proposal was in the Northern Metropolis Development Strategy published by the government in October 2021.

;

;According to this strategy, the wetland conservation parks would have multiple functions including flood prevention.

;

;A rough calculation for Sam Po Shue, based on the water level being able to rise by a metre across half the area, suggests it could accept more than 10 times the capacity of the proposed underground facilities, which should benefit flood-prone Shenzhen on the other side of the river.

;

;Ramsar sites are not intended to be sacrosanct, no-go zones for people, and the strategy also anticipates the wetland conservation parks including aquaculture as well as public education and recreational facilities.

;

;It estimates the total area of the entire system of wetlands and coastal ecological conservation can be about 2,000 hectares, noting: “The entire system can serve as a precious ecological habitat with outdoor recreational resources collectively owned and cherished by all Hong Kong citizens.”

;;2024.05.19 06:00;
;;
;;Model flats being set up at a real estate exhibition in eastern China 。北京强调健康的房地产市场如何与社会福祉和经济发展联系在一起。 Photo: Reuters;
;

;China's “unprecedented” flurry of moves to stabilise its property sector shows the leadership is determined to restore confidence in the economy ahead of a key policy-setting meeting, where “new productive forces” are likely to be in focus, analysts said.

;

;Beijing announced coordinated steps on Friday to address the property sector downturn, with the central bank handing out billions of yuan in extra funding and easing mortgage rules, and local governments encouraged to buy some unsold homes.

;

;The raft of support measures, described as “the boldest” or even “unprecedented” in a decade by many observers, followed inspection tours around the nation by several members of the Politburo Standing Committee, the top decision-making body of the ruling Communist Party.

;

;The traditional field trips came in the lead-up to the party's third plenary session in July, where its top policymaking body – the Central Committee – will set out the country's general economic strategy for the next five to 10 years.

;

;“The new measures certainly show that the authorities want to put a floor under the property slump, at least for the time being,” said George Magnus, a research associate at Oxford University's China Centre.

;

;Vice-premier He Lifeng, who inspected the troubled property sector of Zhengzhou in central Henan province, reiterated how the health of the property market was linked to social wellness and economic development.

;

;“The real estate sector concerns people's interests and the overall situation of China's economic and social development,” He told officials nationwide during a video conference on Friday.

;

;Officials should “profoundly understand” this relevance, He said, urging them to “fight the tough battle” of dealing with unfinished housing projects around the country and help to “assimilate” excess inventory, state news agency Xinhua reported.

;

;The People's Bank of China also said on Friday it would provide 300 billion yuan (US$42.3 billion) in cheap loans to help state-owned enterprises buy unsold housing inventory, apart from easing down payment rules and cutting interest rates for mortgages.

;
;
;

;The property sector, an engine of growth for decades, has become a big drag on the world's No 2 economy as it seeks post-Covid recovery. A Goldman Sachs estimate put China's saleable housing inventory at 13.5 trillion yuan at the end of 2023.

;

;There were 391 million square metres (4.2 billion square feet) of new housing for sale in the first four months of this year, nearly a quarter more than in the same period last year, according to official data. Analysts at Tianfeng Securities estimated it would cost around US$1 trillion to buy the entire stock.

;

;“The third plenum will likely emphasise the point and may well come up with new measures and possibly even an agency to collate funding to buy up inventory, and so channel cash flows to developers,” Magnus at Oxford University said.

;

;“However, the main focus of the plenum is almost certainly going to be on industrial policy and new productive forces.”

;

;“New productive forces”, a catchphrase introduced by President Xi Jinping last year, has been described by him as referring to “advanced productivity freed from traditional economic growth models”, featuring “high technology, high efficiency and high quality”.

;

;According to Magnus: “If China can't stabilise the real estate market and lift confidence among homeowners and the middle class, the new productive forces strategy will count for little, except for favoured firms.”

;

;Real estate generates about a fifth of China's fiscal revenue and accounts for nearly 70 per cent of total household assets, as well as about a quarter of bank loans, official data show.

;

;“The moves send a clear signal that there's real political support from the top leadership for the stabilisation of the property sector,” a political economist said on condition of anonymity as he was not authorised to speak to the media.

;

;“Allowing local governments to buy homes and turn them into subsidised housing will restore confidence and change the public perception that Beijing is hostile to the property sector,” the economist said.

;

;“While it is Xi's catchphrase that 'houses are for living in, not for speculation', it does not mean Beijing wants [the sector] to collapse,” he added.

;

;“The stabilisation of the sector can help spur domestic consumption, boost demand in a vast chain of industries and win time for China's economic restructuring as it tilts towards an innovation-led economy while facing trade tariffs and tech sanctions from the US and its allies.”

;

;Xie Maosong, a senior researcher at the National Institute of Strategic Studies at Tsinghua University, said a healthy property sector not only mattered for public confidence in the economy, but also had significant implications for financial security.

;

;“The national team must come to the rescue.这不仅关系到[陷入困境的]开发商，也关系到中国的经济和金融安全，”谢说。 “Beijing will not allow a property crisis to take place while the US has already initiated a financial war.”

;
;
;

;However, this did not mean China would allow the property sector to become highly speculative again, Xie said.

;

;“There will be a balance between market demand and government intervention in order to achieve a sound recovery of the sector, though the effectiveness largely relies on detailed policies and implementation at local government levels,” he said.

;

;China introduced a slew of forceful measures in 2020 to tackle runaway real estate growth, amid concerns about the economy's overreliance on the sector, rampant speculation that had put housing prices out of reach for most people, and high leverage by developers.

;

;But as prices slumped and developers went bankrupt, authorities started to ease the policies in 2022, with purchase curbs lifted in most cities and banks asked to extend loans to qualified developers.

;

;However, those measures failed to stem the downturn. New home prices fell for a 10th consecutive month in April, registering the fastest month-on-month decline since November 2014. Separate data showed property investment in the first four months of the year falling nearly 10 per cent from a year earlier.

;

;Property sales by floor area in January-April dropped by more than 20 per cent year on year, while new construction starts fell by around 25 per cent. Funds raised by developers also fell by nearly a quarter year on year.

;;中国国家主席习近平与匈牙利总理欧尔班在他们的5月9日，在布达佩斯总理府、前加尔默罗修道院举行会谈。图片来源：法新社;
;

;中国国家主席习近平一定对欧洲五天之行的成果感到满意。自Covid-19大流行爆发以来，这是他首次访问非洲大陆，期间访问了法国、塞尔维亚和匈牙利，在没有花费任何大量外交资本的情况下达成了重要的金融交易。

;

;但习近平的欧洲之行确实做到了这一点不能解决阻碍中欧关系的长期挑战。中国仍面临与欧洲长期战略僵局的风险。

;

;在法国，习近平明智地与法国总统埃马纽埃尔·马克龙 (Emmanuel Macron) 一起呼吁在夏季巴黎奥运会上达成“奥林匹克休战”。乌克兰和加沙。在这样做的过程中，习近平给人留下了和平政治家的印象，但他只需要投入极少的实际政治资本，而这在许多人看来是合理的姿态。

;

;在塞尔维亚，习近平会见了他的对手、总统亚历山大·武契奇(Aleksandar Vucic)，这位友好的领导人通过收购斯梅代雷沃钢厂、修建普平大桥和开发紫金矿业铜盆地等基础设施项目，向中国敞开了国家的经济大门。塞尔维亚经济虽小，但对中国国家主席的欢迎是热烈的。

;

;然而，习近平真正受到庆祝的是在匈牙利。在布达佩斯，他和总理欧尔班·维克多 (Viktor Orban) 对两国蓬勃发展的经济关系表示欢迎，中国电动汽车制造商比亚迪将在匈牙利南部的塞格德开设其在欧洲的第一家工厂，预计每年生产 20 万辆电动汽车。中国支持的布达佩斯-贝尔格莱德高铁建设工作也在快速推进。

;

;所有这些发展都突显了欧洲新兴的、对中国友好的匈牙利-塞尔维亚轴的力量。

;< div>;;

;然而，中国与欧盟的关系仍面临尚未解决的挑战。许多问题仍然摆在桌面上，而通过关注匈牙利和塞尔维亚，中国并不能解决其中任何一个问题。

;

;短期内，讨好欧尔班可能会让习近平的声誉付出巨大代价。多年来，这位匈牙利领导人在大多数欧洲领导人中已经获得了半贱民的地位。他的政府被视为独裁、非自由、民粹主义、民族主义甚至仇外。大多数欧洲国家首都对源自布达佩斯的任何政策都极为警惕。

;

;对于大多数欧洲领导人来说，得到欧尔班的支持并不是一种荣誉徽章。事实上，它被视为应该尽可能避免的事情。通过与欧尔班密切交往，习近平冒着匈牙利领导人极差声誉对中国在欧洲其他国家的形象产生负面影响的风险。

;

;从中期来看，欧尔班是否真的是最佳选择值得怀疑。对于中国来说，在欧洲寻找朋友。当然，只要他掌管布达佩斯，事情就会顺利进行。但是，尽管存在许多严重缺陷，匈牙利仍然是一个民主国家。

;

;迟早，欧尔班将失去对他多年来培育的政治庇护体系以及随之而来的权力的控制。任何接替他的新政府都可能更加自由和亲欧盟。这种状况会给中国带来麻烦，也会给迄今为止取得的政治和经济进展带来巨大风险。

;
;
;

;从长远来看，中国存在着被淘汰的风险。就其与欧盟的关系而言，北京可能高估了北京在布达佩斯购买的影响力的好处。虽然欧尔班可能会尝试反击北京可能认为对其利益或其代理人构成威胁的任何欧盟外交政策举措，但显然正在出现一种趋势，即其他欧洲国家首都正在学习应对布达佩斯的滑稽行为。

;

;当欧尔班试图否决欧盟为乌克兰防御俄罗斯提供额外财政支持时，其他欧盟成员国只是让人们知道他们准备绕开匈牙利提供财政援助。此外，其他欧洲国家首都提出了援引《欧盟条约》第七条的想法，这可能导致匈牙利被剥夺其欧洲理事会投票权。欧尔班迅速做出让步。

;

;随着欧盟正在努力将其外交政策决策过程从一致同意转向特定多数票，匈牙利最终将系统性地在欧洲内部陷入失败的境地。理事会。中国通过北京在布达佩斯拥有的影响力对欧洲外交政策可能产生的任何剩余影响力都将丧失。

;

;至于贝尔格莱德，它对其他欧洲国家首都的影响力将仍然非常有限，直到塞尔维亚被允许加入欧盟。只要武契奇继续掌权，这种情况就不太可能发生。

;

;习近平是一位外交大师，他的欧洲之行处理得非常好。然而，我们必须质疑中国对欧洲的长期战略姿态是否最合适。布鲁塞尔和大多数欧洲国家的首都可能会非常欢迎北京在全球舞台和欧洲经济中发挥更大的作用。

;

;但是，通过与欧洲可能声誉最差的两位领导人变得如此友好，中国可能会蒙羞。它在欧洲其他国家心目中的形象，同时获得的经济和政治收益只是表面的、短期的。
